awd_titl_txt: Heegaard Floer homology, concordance, and categorification
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator will use tools from Heegaard Floer homology to study phenomena in low-dimensional topology. One goal is to better understand the knot concordance group, in particular the difference between the smooth and topological categories. Concordance invariants coming from Floer homology, such as d-invariants and epsilon, are well-suited for this task. Specifically, the principal investigator aims to show that the subgroup of the smooth concordance group generated by topologically slice knots contains an infinite rank summand. A different approach to concordance is via bordered Floer homology. In the same sense that knot Floer homology categorifies the Alexander polynomial, one may hope that the bordered Floer homology of a Seifert surface categorifies the Seifert form. Many classical concordance invariants can be defined in terms of the Seifert form, and the project will investigate how these invariants manifest themselves within the bordered invariants.

The structure of knotted curves in space is intimately related to our understanding of the shape of 3- and 4-dimensional space. Thinking of time as the fourth dimension, the study of knot concordance becomes a question about the evolution of knots over time. By putting different restrictions on how knots may evolve, one obtains different definitions of the complexity of a knot. These measures of complexity have applications from the very small (e.g., the behavior of knotted strands of DNA) to the very large (e.g., the shape of the universe).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary research goal of this project was to use algebraic tools to study knots and surfaces in three-dimensional space. A knot can be thought of as a piece of string that has been twisted and tied in a possibly very complicated way, and then had its ends glued together. A fundamental question in knot theory is how can we tell if two knots are the same; that is, can one knot be wiggled around without cutting so that it looks exactly like the other knot?


One way to help distinguish knots is by using algebraic invariants. More precisely, one defines a systematic way to assign to a knot an algebraic object (for example, a number or a polynomial). Then if two knots have different invariants (e.g., different numbers or polynomials) assigned to them, then the knots themselves must be different.


There is a natural way to add together two knots, and by considering knots that share certain properties to be equivalent, we can endow the set of knots with the structure of a group. An example of a group is the integers: one can add together two integers to get another integer, adding zero results in the same integer, and every integer has an inverse, that is, its negative, which sums with the original integer to be zero.


In her PhD thesis, the PI defined a knot invariant, epsilon, to help understand this group of knots, called the knot concordance group. One of her goals was to use this invariant to better understand the structure of this group, in particular, the difference between requiring maps to be smooth versus merely continuous. This difference is closely related to exotic structures on four-dimensional space. She was able to show that this difference has a rich structure: the corresponding subgroup splits off an infinite rank summand, whereas previously only a rank three summand was known. This work inspired Ozsvath, Stipsicz, and Szabo to define a new invariants, Upsilon, which they then used to reprove her result.


Another approach to understanding knots is to study the surfaces that a knot bounds. For example, a circle is the boundary of a disk, and every knot bounds a (in general, more complicated) surface. In joint work with Lidman and Watson, the PI used a modern invariant called bordered Floer homology, defined by Lipshitz, Ozsvath, and Thurston, to study invariants of such surfaces. Lidman, Watson, and the PI showed that this modern invariant "categorifies" a classical invariant called the Seifert form.


The PI has played a very active role in undergraduate research. During the period of this grant, she supervised 14 undergraduates, resulting in three publications. Many of these undergraduates are now graduate students in mathematics or related fields. Many of her students have presented their research at the Joint Mathematics Meetings; one student, Joshua Tobin, won an Outstanding Poster Presentation award in 2013.


The PI has also been active in organizing workshops and conferences. She co-organized a week-long workshop at the Banff International Research Station in 2016 and a week-long workshop at the Casa Matematica Oaxaca in 2017. For both workshops, she and her co-organizers made an effort to include a diverse group of participants, with a variety of institutions (e.g., both research universities and liberal arts colleges) represented, as well as a focus on including junior participants. At both workshops, roughly one third of the speakers and participants were women. She also co-organized a week-long undergraduate workshop at Georgia Tech in 2017. Thirty five students from across the country came to Atlanta to learn about both research mathematics and career opportunities, present their research, and connect with their peers. About one third of the participants were women, and the majority of the speakers and panelists were women. The participants hailed from a wide range of undergraduate institutions, including small liberal arts colleges such as Haverford, St. John's College, and Calvin College, as well as research institutions ranging from Georgia Southern to Caltech.


Last Modified: 08/17/2017
Modified by: Jennifer C Hom
